Package moulton.scalable.geometrics

Class ShapeResources

  • java.lang.Object
    • moulton.scalable.geometrics.ShapeResources
  • public abstract class ShapeResources
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that provides static shape resources.
    Author:
    Matthew Moulton

    • Field Detail

      • CIRCLE_XS

        public static final java.lang.String[] CIRCLE_XS
        The X values of a "circle" with 32 points. The circle will be centered around "centerx" and will take up the whole width of its parent panel or cell.

      • CIRCLE_YS

        public static final java.lang.String[] CIRCLE_YS
        The Y values of a "circle" with 32 points. The circle will be centered around "centery" and will take up the whole height of its parent panel or cell.

      • TRIANGLE_VERT_XS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_VERT_XS
        The x values for an isosceles triangle that has the two long legs pointing vertically. Can be paired with TRIANGLE_UP_YS to point up, or TRIANGLE_DOWN_YS to point down.

      • TRIANGLE_UP_YS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_UP_YS
        The y values for an upward facing isosceles triangle. Paired with TRIANGLE_VERT_XS.

      • TRIANGLE_DOWN_YS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_DOWN_YS
        The y values for a downward facing isosceles triangle. Paired with TRIANGLE_VERT_XS.

      • TRIANGLE_LEFT_XS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_LEFT_XS
        The x values for a leftward facing isosceles triangle. Paired with TRIANGLE_HORIZ_YS.

      • TRIANGLE_RIGHT_XS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_RIGHT_XS
        The x values for a rightward facing isosceles triangle. Paired with TRIANGLE_HORIZ_YS.

      • TRIANGLE_HORIZ_YS

        public static final java.lang.String[] TRIANGLE_HORIZ_YS
        The y values for an isosceles triangle that has the two long legs pointing horizontally. Can be paired with TRIANGLE_RIGHT_XS to point right, or TRIANGLE_LEFT_XS to point left.

        public ShapeResources()

    • Method Detail

      • generateCircleXCoords

        public static java.lang.String[] generateCircleXCoords​(java.lang.String centerX,
                                                       java.lang.String radius,
                                                       int precision)
        Generates an array of string x coordinates for a circle shape. These x-coordinates are expressions to be solved by MenuComponent.solveString(String,int,int) at run-time in normal rendering. The first coordinate will be the right of the circle, and following coordinates will be listed in a counter-clockwise direction.
        Parameters:
        centerX - the center x-position of the circle expression
        radius - the radius of the circle expression
        precision - indirectly determines the number of points the generated circle will have. Precision of 0 is a square. Precision of 1 is an octagon. Thus the number of points the generated circle will have is 4 + 4*precision
        Returns:
        the array of x coordinates as defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if precision is not greater than 0.

      • generateCircleYCoords

        public static java.lang.String[] generateCircleYCoords​(java.lang.String centerY,
                                                       java.lang.String radius,
                                                       int precision)
        Generates an array of string y coordinates for a circle shape. These y-coordinates are expressions to be solved by MenuComponent.solveString(String,int,int) at run-time in normal rendering. The first coordinate will be the right of the circle, and following coordinates will be listed in a counter-clockwise direction.
        Parameters:
        centerY - the center x-position of the circle expression
        radius - the radius of the circle expression
        precision - indirectly determines the number of points the generated circle will have. Precision of 0 is a square. Precision of 1 is an octagon. Thus the number of points the generated circle will have is 4 + 4*precision
        Returns:
        the array of x coordinates as defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if precision is not greater than 0.
